practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase is necessary because your foundation in React needs to be translated into strict TypeScript definitions to avoid common runtime errors.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Converting existing JS components to TSX with full prop interfaces
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Exercises focused on typing React Event handlers

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Typing primitive props like strings and numbers
difficulty_profile.challenging: Defining complex object shapes and function signatures as props

objective: Zero 'any' types in the codebase
Successful compilation without TS errors
subjective: Your confidence in reading TS error messages increases
Typing props feels like documentation rather than a chore

practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase is necessary because your ability to manage complex application logic depends on correctly typing data flows through hooks and context.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Building a data-driven dashboard using useReducer and Custom Hooks
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Implementing generic components that can handle multiple data types

difficulty_profile.challenging: Creating custom hooks with generic return types and useReducer action unions

objective: Implementation of at least 3 custom generic hooks
Exhaustive switch-case handling in reducers via TS unions
subjective: You feel the IDE autocomplete working for your custom logic
Refactoring feels safer due to type safety

practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase is necessary because your transition to an advanced level requires mastering polymorphic components and enterprise-grade architecture patterns.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Developing a reusable UI component library using 'as' prop polymorphism
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Integrating automated testing for type-level edge cases

difficulty_profile.challenging: Polymorphic components and utility types like Omit/ReturnType

objective: Component library supports dynamic HTML elements with correct type inference
Test suite covers 80% of logic-heavy components
subjective: You can predict where a type will break before the compiler tells you
Your code architecture favors composition over inheritance effortlessly

objective: Codebase 'any' count (Aim for 0)
Number of custom generic components built
Build time stability
Test coverage percentage
subjective: Level of reliance on external documentation for basic TS patterns

architect_notes: You should avoid using 'any' as a shortcut during Cycle 1, as it creates technical debt that undermines the learning of type inference.
Your 10-hour weekly commitment allows for two 3-hour deep work sessions and four 1-hour maintenance sessions.
Prioritize understanding 'Discriminated Unions' early, as they are the backbone of clean React state management.

practice_logs.activity: I applied props to what im learning
I tried the practice without "any". It was hard!
I tried to learn C++ but i was weak

friction_signals: Difficulty rating (8) significantly exceeds the intended 1–5 scale
Fatigue level (7) significantly exceeds the intended 1–5 scale
Short duration (20 mins) coupled with extreme difficulty suggests high cognitive load or frustration
positive_signals: Direct adherence to strategy success marker: 'Zero any types in the codebase'
Active engagement with the most challenging aspect of Cycle 1

analysis_notes: The session difficulty was rated 8/5, indicating the user felt the challenge was far beyond the expected baseline.
User successfully attempted a 'no-any' constraint, which is a key objective of Cycle 1, despite the high perceived difficulty.
Fatigue jumped from 3/4 in earlier sessions to 7/5, signaling a rapid depletion of energy during this specific task.
The discrepancy between the short duration (20m) and high fatigue suggests the cognitive friction of typing without 'any' is currently very high.
